Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Discovering the Evolutionary History of Nocturnality in Birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Historically, transitioning to a nocturnal lifestyle allowed some birds to operate during a time when fewer predators were active and there was less competition for food. Adaptation to nocturnality contributed to the great diversity of birds seen today and that transition likely began with the evolution of night vision. This research will develop a novel method to uncover the ways that birds adapted to see in the dark, and thus became nocturnal. This method incorporates detailed analyses of the genetic foundation of vision in all birds, and will help uncover other modes of avian diversification, such as the origin of diverse plumage coloration. The insights into bird vision gained through this research will be applicable and relevant to research on human vision and visual diseases, such as colorblindness.

Little is known about night vision in birds, but phylogenetic analyses offer evidence of multiple independent origins of this trait and of nocturnality. The DNA sequence capture probe set developed in this proposal will allow isolation and sequencing of the entire phototransduction cascade from the genome of any bird. The phototransduction cascade is a pathway of approximately 30 genes, beginning with the absorption of a photon in an opsin, and resulting in the generation of a neural signal. For this project, these genes will be captured and sequenced from all major nocturnal bird lineages and their diurnal relatives. Analysis of these data will identify evidence of spectral tuning in opsins, evidence for selection, and potential loss or pseudogenization of genes in this cascade. This information will indicate how many times nocturnality has evolved across the avian tree of life, providing insight into the evolutionary origin of those adaptations, whether they were independently derived, represent convergent innovations, or are due to deep homology.

Performance_Institution.Name: Smithsonian Institution National Museum of Natural History

POR.DRECONTENT:
The phototransduction cascade is a network of genes that interact to process the light that enters the eye into a signal for the brain to recognize light, color, shape, etc. It is the gene network that underlies vision, and it is very well conserved in all vertebrates. Birds are well known to have excellent vision, and can even see colors that humans cannot. Birds also display a wide variety in ability to see and response to visual cues. For example, the birds of paradise have elaborate feather structures and coloration, and are known to dance for their partners. There are also nocturnal birds, which have eyes adapted to see in extremely low-light conditions (only the moon and stars for illumination) and which can catch insects while in flight. Because of this variety, birds are an excellent system with which to study vision. The goal of this project was to create a tool that would help researchers study the molecular basis of vision in all birds.

First, 47 genes representing all components of the phototransduction cascade, and a few relevant genes related to coloration and other visual processes, were selected. Their sequences were used to generate a probe set based on these genes. When mixed in solution, these probes could be combined with DNA from an entire bird’s genome, to extract only these genes of interest for sequencing. Second, these probe sequences were hybridized to published bird genes in computer simulations (in silico testing). Many iterations of this in silico testing were performed to determine the best of the available avian genomes to be used in the first synthesis. This process ensured that the funds of this grant would not be wasted on the synthesis and in vitro (in the lab) testing of inaccurate loci.

Once the probe set was verified, it was synthesized and tested in vitro in 32 species of birds. These 32 species represented a shallow, but broad, sampling of the avian tree of life. The probe set was effective at extracting sequences across all of the samples tested in the study. On average, sequence from 91% of the genes targeted was captured from every single bird.

This project expanded my doctoral thesis into functional biology, which provided an entirely new facet to my work. Through conducting this research, I have gained a greatly increased understanding of genome sequencing and the workings of the phototransduction cascade, and I have learned several important techniques such as the analysis of genome-scale data and probe set design. These techniques provide me with the tools to expand my research to comparative biology, and has prepared me for my future career as an independent research scientist.

I have shared this research with the scientific communities at the University of Maryland, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), the National Institutes of Health's National Eye Institute, and at multiple international meetings. I have presented this research to the public at several events including the Senate of Scientists symposium at NMNH, “Museum Day Live!” at the NMNH, and at two “Expert is In” events at the NMNH. The latter two events are "meet and greet" style events, where I set up a table with interactive activities and displays in a public space of the museum to interact with visitors one-on-one. In addition, a recording of my Senate of Scientists talk is available to the public on my research website.

This probe set will make it easy for any bird biologist (or vision evolution biologist) to efficiently sequence all of the genes of the phototransduction cascade in one reaction. It will greatly expedite the sequencing of these genes, saving alot of time for the researcher. This probe set will be widely used by researchers studying any questions relevant to vertebrate vision, including sexual selection, behavior, development, etc. Because of the ease of use of this tool, it will enable researchers who are not necessarily experts in genomic techniques to generate useful data.

This project will impact studies of vision in other groups of organisms, including humans. By bringing to light the way that nature has solved the problem of seeing in low-light conditions in birds, advances could be made in the treatment of human eye diseases, as well as technologies for improving nightvision (such as those used in defense). This project will help society better understand the origins of biodiversity and how the Earth came to be. Understanding the world around us both fulfills a deep human desire, but also allows us to understand how to conserve the world for a sustainable future. In addition, many inventions stem from an inspiration seen in nature--a phenomenon known as biomimicry. Understanding nature and how it works is the first step in biomimicry.
